text:
Passage:
The city introduced a weekly car-free hour on major roads to encourage walking and cycling. Local shops reported higher footfall, while residents noted clearer air and a calmer soundscape.

Q: Primary purpose of the measure?
explanation: Answer follows directly from the passage.

text:
Passage:
A small library launched a 'take-a-book, leave-a-book' shelf. Over time, readers curated the shelf with diverse titles, and the habit built a friendly ritual around sharing stories.

Q: The shelf policy was:
explanation: Answer follows directly from the passage.

One-word substitute: One who does something for the first time

Meaning of the idiom: "Hit the sack"
options_json: ["Make people feel more comfortable","Reveal a secret","Undecided","Go to sleep"]

text: Meaning of the idiom: "In a nutshell"
She _____ to the market every Sunday.
I _____ my work by 6 PM yesterday.
They _____ cricket when it started to rain.
He _____ the project next week.
We _____ dinner when he arrived.
She _____ the report already.
The team _____ the match by noon tomorrow.
explanation: Future simple for a scheduled completion.

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["Each of the boys have a pen.","Each of the boys has a pen.","Each  of the boys have a pen.","each of the boys has a pen."]
explanation: Correct form uses ""has"" with ""Each of the boys"".

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["She do not like tea.","She does not like tea.","she does not like tea.","She does not likes tea."]

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["He is senior than me.","He is senior to me.","he is senior to me.","He  is senior than me."]
explanation: Senior to"" is the correct idiom.

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["Neither of the two are correct.","Neither  of the two are correct.","Neither of the two is correct.","neither of the two is correct."]
explanation: Use singular verb with ""Neither of the two"".

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["The sceneries here are beautiful.","The scenery here is beautiful.","the scenery here is beautiful.","Scenery here are beautiful."]
explanation: Scenery"" is uncountable and takes singular verb.

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["He is living here since 2010.","He has been living here since 2010.","he has been living here since 2010.","He had been living here since 2010."]

text: Choose the grammatically correct sentence:
options_json: ["I am knowing the answer.","I knows the answer.","I know the answer.","i know the answer."]
explanation: Use simple present: ""I know the answer.""

text:
Arrange the parts to form a coherent paragraph:
C. Local musicians performed throughout the day.
A. The festival drew visitors from many cities.
D. The park was decorated with lights and banners.
B. Stalls offered regional snacks and handicrafts.
explanation: Logical flow: A (overview) → B (stalls) → C (music) → D (decor).

text:
Arrange the parts to form a coherent paragraph:
B. Teams formed around shared interests.
A. The workshop began with a quick warm-up.
D. By evening, prototypes were shown.
C. Mentors guided the brainstorming.
explanation: Logical flow: A → B → C → D.

text:
All poets are dreamers. Some dreamers are teachers.
Which conclusion follows?
options_json: ["Some poets may be teachers.","All dreamers are poets.","No teacher is a poet.","Some teachers are not dreamers."]

text:
No apples are blue. Some fruits are apples.
Which conclusion follows?
options_json: ["Some fruits are not blue.","All fruits are blue.","Some apples are blue.","No fruits are blue."]
